very different state OF things exist, as it respects
The relation between the two organic departments,
for has puzzled the utmost efforts OF human 'nge-

an animal and vegetable, or to decide where one
begins and the other ends Hence naturalsts have

to certain indeterminate class of organized bodies
to which they have given the name Of Zoophytes
word denoting that these bodies partake both o
the nature Of an animal, and vegetable. Ih
order comprises about five hundred species. lh'
coral, the sponge. and the polypus, are members
this singular family. The polypus may be turned
inside out and yet live it may be cut into pieces
aud each piece possessing the astonishing propert,
of producing head and tail, and all the organs ne
'cessary to life, will thus, in a few days, become
perfect polypus.

in the hands of tenants, and managed according 10
his directions and system of husbandy, had been 50
productive appears in the following extract OF Inc
Address of John Lowell, Esq. President OF the
Massachusetts Agricultural Society, delivered at the
late Cattle Show at Brighton.


Mr.. Coke, Of Norfolk, whose name ought to DC
familiar with every American well as British TAR
mer, inherited some 35 years since, great landed
estate in Norfolk the whole rental OF which was
only $4,000, OF $500 year; being an active anu
intelligent man, he introduced the Tullian husbana'
ry, which consists in frequent rotations OF crops
and in sowing in drills in short, IN more
spirited use of the plough and other improved III
struments. In the lifetime of this one man. and ne
is still alive, by the plough alone and by adopting
proper SUGGESTIONS of plans he has raised his rent
al from $500 to 100000 year in other woros'
increased the value of his estate "a times. NO
specuations in banks, mining discoveries-no'
not even Potos in its virgin state, when silver was
found upon the surface, can show such an 'p-
preciation of property as has been produceu y
skill, enlightened skill, applied to the surface
Yet all this has been effected by tenants ho'
o7rners Of the soil, but under lease for q years
subject to the hazards of refusal to rene" 'ne
lease, by less enlightened heir. These are 'a'p'
not to be disputed, and they prove that agriculture
in the short space of mans life, has undergone
improvements of which antiquity has no conceP'
ton.'
FARMING TO SOME PURPOSE.

Conventions for nominating Electors favourable
to Mr.. Adams, have been called in Pennsylvania on
the 4th January in New-Jersey, on the 26h OF
December in Louisiana on the LIST of November !;
in Kentucky, on the 18th December; and In VIZ
ginia, on the 9Th January.
CONVENTIONS.

General Jacksons conduct towards Mr. Loual- it
er, member Of the Legislature Of Louisiana, m
some time after the battle of New Orleans, has cl
been the subject of many remarks, and much dis Ii
cusson, both among his partisans and his opposers
His opposers have called it illegal and unconsti IN
tutona, and OF course tyrannical and oppressive
His friends have justified it the ground of state Il
necessty-charging Mr.. Louallier with mutny or f
exciting muny. with being spy, sc. &c. NJ Il
Louallier has recently published history of the Ii
transaction which has given rise to the following az
tice. 1t seems that he inserted an article in al 8
newspaper on the Sd of March, 1915 complaining i
of an order of General Jacksons commanding the
Frenchmen residing in New Orleans to leave that
place in three days, and to keep themselves at a
distance Of 100 miles from the city. For this he
was arrested, and imprisoned !; and then broughtl
before court martial, to answer to no less than
seven charges above mentioned, all arising out OF
the article thus published. After denying the juris
dction and authority of the court martial, and be-
ing overruled, he suffered the to 60 with
out calling witness, or making any defence.
He was however acquitted. General jackson
hsapproved of the sentence of course and gave
his reasons. As soon as Mr.. Louaier was ar
rested, he applied to judge Hail. of the district
Court OF the United States, for Habeas Cor
Pms which in his case, from Judge Lewis--a
Judge under the state authority--for procuring
which the attorney was arrested, and an order
issued by General Jackson for arrestlng Judge Lew
is for granting the Hlbea: Corpus in favor OF Judge
Hail. Here then we're three arrests and an order
for fourth under the authority of General Jack
son, in the proceedings relating to which, the rights
and security OF the several individuals were totally
dsregarted. and the authority and sanctty of the
civil laws utterly despised, and tramped under foot
1t must be acknowledged that strong necessity mus
have existed to justify such outrageous proceedings
We will endeayor to ascertain the facts respecting
it.


The battle of New Orleans it will be recolect
ed, happened on the 9Th of January, 1915. Oh
Z" the 2lst Of January, General jackson and the sr
my left the field Of battle to return to NJ Orleans.
Two regiments receiv ed orders to encamp at IL plac
called Where's plantation. s' 1t will easily be ina
gned,'' says Mr.. Loualer, how painful, such a
order must have been for those two regiments
which, part of the levy ea masse, were com
posed OF the greater part Of the citizens OF Ne,
Orleans, between the ages of f3 and 10 years
These militia men were deeply wounded at bein
thus deprived of the happiness of returning to tn
bosom of their families, at the same time that h
favor was granted to the battalion Of volunteers ur
der the command of Major Plache, and the colore
inen under major Daguen." Why did he retail
these militia men without the city, while the other
and even the corps of regulars, allowed to Ell
Ger t?'' In this state Of things, would seem, an
in cons equence Of the uneasness felt and expressed
General Jackson issued his perGmptory order II
the removal of the Frenchmen in the city, to tn
distance Of 100 miles in the country. That the
should have been uneasy, is not strange not mere
because they were unnecessarily and arbitrarily ke
from their families and homes but they were pr
bably appreheusive of the effects Of their exposu
to the most destructive Diseases 1t is stated in
of the documents accompanying Mr.. Louaers a
count, that the troops from Kentucky and Tennc
were stationed upon plantations, and that in o,
month no less than live hundred of them fell vi
Tins to diseases which originated among them.


What makes Gen. 5ackson's condLct towards
Louallier the more remarkable is, that tile public
ton which was the Of it, appeared, as is asst
ted by that gentleman, 43 days after Gen. Jacks
had left the field of battle, and returned to New {
leans-43 days after the British had left Louisiana
and % days after the last act Of hostility comm
ted by the British forces as their officers receiv
intelligence Immediately afterwards that treaty
peace had been signed in Dec. between the U Sta
and Great Britain. 1t was also FL days after G
Livingston had returned from the British fleet, q
informed Gen. Jackson that news OF peace had be
received, and above all it was SO days after &


Jackson had written to the Secretary of War t


in his opinion, Louisiana might be considered


freed from her enemies


Under circumstances like these and when Il,


was no possible excuse for any measure of vioet


Gen. jackson. without law orrieht, and in the


of all law, and all constitutional authority.


Clby arrested private citizen, in no ,respect {


ject to his contro having military charac


tut being Of such an aye that he was not BY law


BILE to military duty, threw him into prison, orde


am before coars martial, and had him tried

LATEST FROM EUROPE,

The Phila'd. Bible Soc'y. following the example
of that of New-Jersey, have resolved that an i'm
mediate effort be made to supply every destitute
family in the State of Pennsy ylvania with copy of the
sacred Scriptures, without note OF comment, within
the term of three years, and sooner if it shall be
found practicable In the Address of the Managers
of the Society to the inhabitants of Pennsylvania, it


is calculated that one fourth, or $500 families in
that State, are now destitute of the Scriptures.

Eleven persons now i'll at our Poor HOUSE
with disease wearing the aspect of Small Fox,

the maady has appeared in those who have passe"
through the Vaccin inc dseas.

Mr.. Coke, Of Norfolk, whose name ought to DC

only $4,000, OF $500 year; being an active anu

and in sowing in drills in short, IN more
spirited use of the plough and other improved III
struments. In the lifetime of this one man. and ne
is still alive, by the plough alone and by adopting
proper SUGGESTIONS of plans he has raised his rent
al from $500 to 100000 year in other woros'
increased the value of his estate "a times. NO
specuations in banks, mining discoveries-no'
not even Potos in its virgin state, when silver was
found upon the surface, can show such an 'p-

Yet all this has been effected by tenants ho'

The Phila'd. Bible Soc'y. following the example
of that of New-Jersey, have resolved that an i'm
mediate effort be made to supply every destitute
family in the State of Pennsy ylvania with copy of the
sacred Scriptures, without note OF comment, within
the term of three years, and sooner if it shall be
found practicable In the Address of the Managers
of the Society to the inhabitants of Pennsylvania, it


is calculated that one fourth, or $500 families in
that State, are now destitute of the Scriptures.
